channel.title: How to Start a Server on Mac OSX
channel.description:
[size=18pt]A Guide to Running/Starting a Runescape Private Server on a Macintosh Computer[/size]
I am doing this guide for pure educational purposes only. I have noticed a lack of voice for Mac users in the community. I am here to fix that. It can be a long road to a working server on mac due to compatibility issues. I, with the help of Ry60003333, have gotten around most of these problems. I learned all my knowledge from Ryan, but I am willing to share it with the community.
First off, let me explain some things:
[ul][li]Macintosh computers are easily conquered if you have the right tools, a brain, willingness to learn, and a sense of patience.[/li] [li]It doesn't matter what version you have, but I can only really limit questions to Mac OSX and Snow Leopard.[/li] [li]Sine there is no execution file type on mac (like there is on windows), compiling and running can be a bit more difficult. [/li] [li]A few terminal commands will get your right around these simple processes, but may help you learn something.[/li] [li]The simple run command (will vary) is: Java -Xmx500m server (Note: 500m refers to 500mb. Adjust this as you see fit.)[/li] [li]The Compiling command can be tricky on the first try. I will explain it later.[/li][/ul]
Lets get started.
I think we all know by now that Macs are different from Windows. Macintosh comes with JDK and Java pre-installed!! :eek:
To start a server, basic knowledge of drag-and-drop is assumed.
Step 1: Get a source. Server Downloads: [url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/board,49.0.html]http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/board,49.0.html[/url] Step 2: A no-ip account is assumed to be in your possession. [url=http://www.no-ip.com/]http://www.no-ip.com/[/url]
Step 3: Log into your account, Click "Manage Hosts", Click "Add a host" [img]http://grab.by/21eT[/img]
Step 4: Fill in the ip address box with the ip address from this website. [url=http://ipchicken.com/]http://ipchicken.com/[/url]
Step 5: Select DNS Host A, choose your name in the Hostname box, and click create. Step 6: Download the No-Ip Duc for Macintosh. [url=http://www.no-ip.com/client/mac/noip3.1.4.dmg]http://www.no-ip.com/client/mac/noip3.1.4.dmg[/url] Step 7: Download, Install, and Update that. Step 8: Portforwarding. A. Click the Network button in the upper right corner of the screen and click on "Open Network Preferences." [img]http://grab.by/21g7[/img]
B. Click TCP/IP. Look for Router: 192.167.0.2 or a variation of that. Copy and paste it in your browser. [img]http://grab.by/21gu[/img]
C. Login with either, User: "Admin" & Pass: "Admin"; U: "Admin" & P: ""; or if you have changed it, you know ;) D. Navigate to some form of Advanced>Port-forwarding E. Fill in the required boxes. a) Ip Address: Navigate to Network Preferences in System Preferences just like you did in step 8A. Look for the network you are connected to. In my case, it was "The Hallmans." You will know because under the network, it will say "Connected." Look for "'Your Computer Name' is connected to 'Network Name' with the ip address 'XXX.XXX.X.XXX'." This will be the ip you use in the Ip Address box in port-forwarding. b) TCP: 43594 "Always Allow" or "Allow All" c) (If you have) UDP: 43594 "Allows Allow" or "Allow All" d) Save settings and restart your router.
F. Congratulations, you have now port-forwarded.
Step 9: Compiling. Note: Some sources are not compatible for mac. It would be impossible to convert some of the methods called using Windows. You will just have to suffice. A. Find your source in a New Finder window. [img]http://grab.by/21ir[/img]
B. Open a terminal window adjacent to it. [img]http://grab.by/21iG[/img]
Type this: "cd " (with the space after it) Now, look at your finder window. Do you see the folder Icon next to the title of the client's folder? Click and Drag it to the terminal window and let go. You should now have: [img]http://grab.by/21ja[/img]
Press return. Type "javac *.java" (without quotes). Press return.
If your source is compatible, it should have no errors. Somethings can be fixed easily so post here if you get errors. [img]http://grab.by/21ji[/img]
Step 10: Running.
Find your servers run.bat file, open it, and copy the line that says something along the lines of "java -Xmx500m server" [img]http://grab.by/21l6[/img]
Paste it into the same terminal window as you just compiled, (assuming you got no errors.)
Note: If your run command has semicolons in it, change those to colons. This is a compatibility issue from Windows to Macintosh.
Example: [code]java -Xmx512m -cp .;./jython.jar;./MySql/mysql-connector-java-3.0.08-ga-bin.jar server[/code] should be changed to [code]java -Xmx512m -cp .:./jython.jar:./MySql/mysql-connector-java-3.0.08-ga-bin.jar server[/code]
Press enter. You should get a message saying your server is up and running! [img]http://grab.by/21k9[/img]
CONGRATULATIONS. You have finally gotten a server on your Macintosh computer.
Post any errors you might get when running, they can vary, but we can usually fix them.
::FOR THE ADVANCED ONLY::
This mini-section will be about making a Shell. This is an easy way to run a server or client. Note: Shell files are the equivalent to a batch file in Windows.
Refer to step 10 to get your run command.
A shell that compiles and runs: [img]http://grab.by/21lB[/img]
A shell that just runs: [img]http://grab.by/21lF[/img]
To create a shell, open TextEdit. Make a new File. Format>Make plain text. Fill the file with the desired elements and save it as the corresponding name with the extension .sh [img]http://grab.by/21lU[/img]
To run a shell: Open terminal, type "bash " and drag the shell file into terminal. Hit enter. It should have worked if you created on correctly. [img]http://grab.by/21lZ[/img]
::::
I do not expect a Thanks from every person that reads this, but some would be appreciated.
Constructive criticism is encouraged, and appreciated. Posts such as "this sucks" are not appreciated and will be ignored to the fullest.
[size=8pt]This guide was written by Tanner, "delicious", in full enjoyment for the Moparscape Community on Wednesday, January 27, 2010 at 6:30 PM.
All Rights Reserved. Copyright 2010. Runescape does not belong to me. It is property of Jagex, Ltd. I take no credit for the creation of the game, or anything affiliated with Runescape itself. By reading this guide, you accept that I am the original creator of this, and by all means, if you decide to post it elsewhere, give me credit, Tanner, "delicious" from Moparscape. That is all I ask. [/size]

item.title: How to Start a Server on Mac OSX
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“Sideoutkid, post:78, topic:327408”]So while trying to compile I get this -

[quote]Brandons-MacBook-Pro:Rune-Evo v3 brandongunda$ javac *.java
javac: file not found: *.java
Usage: javac
use -help for a list of possible options
Brandons-MacBook-Pro:Rune-Evo v3 brandongunda$

[/quote]

Does that mean I’m missing a file?[/quote]There are no java files in the directory you’re running the command in.

Read full topic
item.source: How to Start a Server on Mac OSX

Basaks-MacBook-Pro:OverloadX 317 Source basak$ javac *.java

item.title: How to Start a Server on Mac OSX
item.dc:creator: @blackflag1 blackflag_
item.description:
@blackflag1 wrote:

[quote=“Goodbye RS, Hello RSPS, post:6, topic:327408”]Ew. Everybody hates mac. And mac fails. And linux rules. And windows rules. And apple fails.

And to be honest you could tell the retards to download this sh file.

And note that servers do not need to be run on the xmx execution.

And for compile.

javac *.java[/quote]
i don’t care how old this post is; you’re an idiot

Anyways, mac & linux work the same way with this shit, simply changing a .bat format to a .sh . You shouldn’t be using batch/shell files anyways. Should of wrote this guide to encourage people to use IDEs rather than all this command-line stuff.

java is one language and will work on any OS. There are so many IDEs out there to work on any OS to handle all of this, and it will definitely help you fixing/finding errors & writing code more easily

Read full topic
item.source: How to Start a Server on Mac OSX

item.title: How to Start a Server on Mac OSX
item.dc:creator: @i_have_an_ax i have an ax
item.description:
@i_have_an_ax wrote:

I know this is almost a year and half old, but I came across a problem in step 8. In the AirPort window, there’s nothing that says Network Preferences for me (I’m using 10.4). I checked System Prefences -> Network, but nothing about TCP/IP or a router. I tried looking for my router address online, but I tried several of them and they didn’t work.

Hopefully I can get this problem sorted out and continue making an RSPS. In the meantime, is there a mac private server that’s up and running?

Read full topic

@mata20000 wrote:

I have done all you said. Iv compiled with no error, i changed my ; to : in the runserver.bat. Then when i run it it says running and next line files not found and then when i go on moparscape and try log on it gives does next errors. In windows i had run this server about a year ago perfectly and smoothly but in mac it does not seem to be able to read some of the files or idk. Heeelp plz. thanks. Errors shown down

**********-MacBook-Pro:Copy of Project Pownedscape v.3 *******$ java -Xmx512m -cp .:./Class: server
Starting Pmgzscape on 0.0.0.0:43594

The banned IPs file could not be accessed.

item.title: How to Start a Server on Mac OSX
item.dc:creator: @lostgrace lostgrace
item.description:
@lostgrace wrote:

Does anyone have a 508 or 562 source thats mac compatible and that they can confirm works? Can anyone also go more indepth on how to compile and such?

Read full topic
item.source: How to Start a Server on Mac OSX
